dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Over 150 points—the Dow jumped that much at Thursday's open.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Over one hundred fifty points-the Dow jumped that much at Thursday's open.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.6%, over 150 points, at Thursdays open, while the S&P 500 fell 0.6% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite lost 0.9%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the S&P and Nasdaq were up too, around 0.6% and 0.9%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the S&P and Nasdaq were up too, around zero point six percent and zero point nine percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.6%, over 150 points, at Thursdays open, while the S&P 500 fell 0.6% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite lost 0.9%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A lot of it seems tied to unemployment data, like, 900,000 fewer claims last week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A lot of it seems tied to unemployment data, like, nine hundred thousand fewer claims last week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Stocks fell after jobless claims data came in slightly worse than expected, with 1.3 million more Americans filing for unemployment in the week ending July 11, according to the Labor Department.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's a pretty solid improvement, right? Though retail sales did drop 7.5% in June.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a pretty solid improvement, right? Though retail sales did drop seven point five percent in June.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Retail sales jumped by 7.5% in Junehigher than the 5.2% expected, but lower than last months record surge of 17.7%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, not as bad as expected, but still down from that huge surge last month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, not as bad as expected, but still down from that huge surge last month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Retail sales jumped by 7.5% in Junehigher than the 5.2% expected, but lower than last months record surge of 17.7%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then you've got these bank earnings—Citibank beat estimates, stock up almost 4%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you've got these bank earnings-Citibank beat estimates, stock up almost four percent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: They set aside a billion dollars for pandemic-related stuff, which investors liked, I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They set aside a billion dollars for pandemic-related stuff, which investors liked, I guess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Major banks, meanwhile, continued to kick off second quarter earnings season: Bank of America topped estimates but its stock fell nearly 4% as the company set aside $4 billion for coronavirus-related losses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile JP Morgan missed expectations, their shares fell almost 1%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile J P Morgan missed expectations, their shares fell almost one percent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oof, fixed income trading revenue dropped 170%? That's brutal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oof, fixed income trading revenue dropped one hundred seventy percent? That's brutal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Morgan Stanley shares rose by almost 1% after the bank easily beat analyst expectations thanks to surging trading revenueswith its revenue from fixed income traders increasing by 170% last quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then Facebook's up over 3% after their digital currency launch, even with the hack.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then Facebook's up over three percent after their digital currency launch, even with the hack.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares of social media platform Twitter dropped more than 3% following a massive digital currency scam late on Wednesday: Hackers gained access to dozens of high-profile accounts, including Tesla CEO Elon Musk, former vice president Joe Biden and Microsoft cofounder Bill Gates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, hackers got into accounts like Elon Musk's and… Bill Gates', right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, hackers got into accounts like Elon Musk's and... Bill Gates', right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hackers gained access to dozens of high-profile accounts, including Tesla CEO Elon Musk, former vice president Joe Biden and Microsoft cofounder Bill Gates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, high-profile targets. But the market just shrugged it off apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, high-profile targets. But the market just shrugged it off apparently.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Kind of wild how vaccine news from Pfizer earlier in the week had dragged things down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kind of wild how vaccine news from Pfizer earlier in the week had dragged things down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, stocks rallied on positive coronavirus vaccine news from Moderna and strong earnings results from Goldman Sachs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but then infection rates are improving—under 10,000 new cases this week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but then infection rates are improving-under ten thousand new cases this week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But recent gains come amid a backdrop of surging coronavirus infections across the country, however: The U.S. reported a new daily record of more than 67,000 cases earlier this week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So it's like, good news bad news, but investors are leaning optimistic today.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's like, good news bad news, but investors are leaning optimistic today.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The market opened lower on Thursday, with more big banks reporting second quarter earnings, as investors grappled with the latest economic data showing the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.

artist_script:
HostA: Over 150 points—the Dow jumped that much at Thursday's open.
HostB: Yeah, and the S&P and Nasdaq were up too, around 0.6% and 0.9%.
HostA: A lot of it seems tied to unemployment data, like, 900,000 fewer claims last week.
HostB: That’s a pretty solid improvement, right? Though retail sales did drop 7.5% in June.
HostA: Mhm, not as bad as expected, but still down from that huge surge last month.
HostB: And then you’ve got these bank earnings—Citibank beat estimates, stock up almost 4%.
HostA: They set aside a billion dollars for pandemic-related stuff, which investors liked, I guess.
HostB: Meanwhile JP Morgan missed expectations, their shares fell almost 1%.
HostA: Oof, fixed income trading revenue dropped 170%? That’s brutal.
HostB: And then Facebook’s up over 3% after their digital currency launch, even with the hack.
HostA: Wait, hackers got into accounts like Elon Musk’s and… Bill Gates’, right?
HostB: Yeah, high-profile targets. But the market just shrugged it off apparently.
HostA: Kind of wild how vaccine news from Pfizer earlier in the week had dragged things down.
HostB: True, but then infection rates are improving—under 10,000 new cases this week.
HostA: So it’s like, good news bad news, but investors are leaning optimistic today.
